page.title: 08THE GARDEN VILLAGE CONCEPT
page.content: In 1925 Capt Reiss,an expert in town planning asked eminent architects Tait Hennell and Quennel to design varied houses for the garden village.The aim was low density housing,ample gardens, tree lined avenues,playing fields and central shops.Hennell and Quennel designed simply styled neo-Georgian houses with hipped roofs,including F. Crittall's house in the village centre Tait's "modern movement style" (plain shapes,flat roofs,horizontal bands of windows + projecting canopies) were developed to the full in D.Crittall's house,Le Chateau and managers'houses, Craig Angus and Wolverton,(now listed buildings).In 1969 the houses became Council property,being changed very little until 1980 when tennants began to buy them.A conservation area was drawn around the original garden village in 1982,amidst controversy.
